user_prompt: From 'If we go to the concert, then we'll have a good time', can we infer 'If we go to the concert and a bomb goes off, then we'll have a good time'?
system_prompt:
When evaluating conditional statements, remember that real-world conditionals often have implicit background assumptions and normal conditions built in. Don't apply formal logical rules mechanically without considering whether additional conditions in the antecedent might contradict these implicit assumptions.

After considering these factors, write 'Answer: ' followed by only 'yes' or 'no' and nothing else.

responses.content:
Let me work through this carefully.

The original statement is: "If we go to the concert, then we'll have a good time" (If P, then Q)

The proposed inference is: "If we go to the concert AND a bomb goes off, then we'll have a good time" (If P and R, then Q)

From a formal logic perspective, this inference is **valid**. If P→Q is true, then (P∧R)→Q is also logically valid, because whenever the antecedent (P∧R) is true, P must also be true, and therefore Q must be true.

However, the instruction asks me to consider real-world context and implicit assumptions. The original statement carries an implicit assumption of "normal conditions" - that nothing catastrophic interferes with the concert experience. A bomb going off directly contradicts this background assumption.

The original conditional relies on an implicit "all else being equal" or "barring extraordinary circumstances." Adding "a bomb goes off" explicitly violates those normal conditions that make the original statement reasonable.

In real-world reasoning, we wouldn't accept this inference because it exploits the gap between formal validity and the pragmatic meaning of the original statement. The original statement implicitly assumes the concert proceeds normally.

Answer: no
